keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.
The death toll includes 29 in Veracruz, 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
65 people are still missing, with 43 in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and emergency aid.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply to 263,000 affected users.
Governors and federal authorities are coordinating response efforts across the affected states.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no early meteorological signs indicating the extreme rainfall severity, raising questions about Mexico’s disaster alert systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding in five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 missing persons. The worst-hit areas were Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths), with over 100,000 homes affected. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and medical aid. Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity to 263,000 users. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua highlighted the scale of the disaster and noted a lack of early meteorological warnings, raising concerns about Mexico’s disaster preparedness systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
